WRITING.TEXT: Upvote for Canticle for Leibowitz. Despite being a huge fan of that book and the Fallout series, I somehow never connected them.
Finally, a Tumblr post I support fully.
http://www.killermovies.com/forums/archive/index.php/t-293669-the-silmarillion-in-1000-words.html
You hit the nail on the head. That is the perfect analogy. I am now stealing it. Complaining about me stealing it would make you kleptonormative and a racist.

I was also sad about the absence of the witches, but I realized recently that they're showing up in his YA Discworld novels (the Tiffany Aching series). I initially avoided reading them because I didn't want to be disappointed by "dumbed down" Pratchett, but I was looking for 8th grade graduation gifts for some of my ~~minions~~ students, and I wanted to know if they were good. They are. Very much so. All the brilliance of Pratchett, with only minor tweaking for the YA audience. It loses none of what makes his books great. So hopefully I created some new fans.
That being said, my favorites were always the Watch. I still want to be Captain Carrot when I grow up.
Thank you for pointing this out. Even with the croissant story, it never would have occurred to me that this question could be interpreted that way.

WRITING.TEXT:
My first thought: "You're adopting your wife?"
...I need more sleep.

Well, I can't think of anyone I know being exterminated by the Church, either. Of course, there's such a thing as a latae sententiae excommunication, where people excommunicate themselves through obstinate rejection of doctrine. I think a round of excommunications for public figures would do wonders, but the bishops seem to be too afraid of backlash.

No no no, it's:
EXCOMMUNICATE! EXCOMMUNICATE!
[As seen here](http://37.media.tumblr.com/tumblr_m04hp62isf1r31epfo1_500.jpg)

Well, considering that Catholics believe that taking the Eucharist unworthily (in a state of mortal sin) or while not being in communion with the Catholic Church is in fact harmful to a person's spiritual well-being, it's possible the priest was simply panicked out of concern for her well-being and reacted on impulse. It's also possible he's a jerk who was trying to shame her in front of the congregation. I don't know the man, but I tend to assume good motives unless proven otherwise. Does he have a history of this sort of treatment of others?
He'll have his revenge in 50 years when they try to put President Obama's face on the $500 bill.

At first I thought that the joke was that there was no Metal Gear Solid 5 yet....then I realized I'm just old and out of touch. I swear I'll make it through this backlog of games and play something from the past 5 years soon...

I drive by the school on my way to work every day. I went to that school growing up. My parents live near several of the families whose children died. I recognized at least one last name as the same last name as a guy I went to school with from elementary to high school - no idea if the girl was related to him though. One of my students had an aunt who was one of the adults killed, and I currently teach another student who transferred in after his sister was killed. If anyone said something like this to my face, I might legitimately slug them. They have no idea how hard this rocked the community here. If there were some kind of stupid conspiracy attempt, it would have taken all of 10 minutes to break, since so many families here know each other and would have noticed "Jerry never had a son" or "Gayle's daughter is fine - they just moved away last year." The lengths people will go to to believe that there is some secret cabal orchestrating everything and there aren't just crazy or evil buggers who occasionally do bad things...

Lifelong Sandy Hook resident here. There were minor memorials done here in town, like the one at my church. We, as a community, basically told the media to eff off during the anniversary. There were signs all over the area and all lawns of businesses and major gathering locations saying that the media was requested to stay away. Our First Selectman made official statements to this effect as well, and we had police presence all over town to enforce this. Many of the families involved went away on vacation to avoid any potential intrusions. We wanted to keep it private and in-house rather than having media dredge up old feelings for their own sensationalism.

Hmm, well they do have a bit of "Haha, those silly menfolk don't realize what we tricksy womenzes are actually doing behind their back to actually run things," maybe? I still really enjoy the books and the characters, but I can see that as being a tad grating for some people. For me, I probably least enjoyed the Rincewind/wizards books, which isn't saying much considering I love the whole series. I also can't put my finger on why.

You have a very valid point from a literary standpoint, but I would like to point out that this actually does happen more often than you think.
Source: Getting to that age and have female friends

Sorry if I came off as snarky. I was legitimately just trying to explain and clarify the teaching.

Don't know where you got that impression, but that's not true. Purgatory is a defined doctrine, so it can't be changed by any council. Perhaps you were thinking of Limbo? That's always been theological speculation so there's no definite teaching on it. It's open to personal interpretation whether or not it exists.
Demolition Man. Three seashells replace toilet paper in the future. How is still a mystery, to the main character and the audience.

Well, I wouldn't have capitalized "theists", either. Atheism is more of a classification than a specific belief system. It often implies philosophical materialism and empiricism, but not always. It's too broad to be considered a denomination. So I'd say it's not a proper noun.

Well, it is true that anyone can get to Heaven, but your time in Purgatory is based on how much junk needs to be cleaned out of your soul before you're fit for Heaven, not what religion you followed. Though hopefully if you're Catholic you have less since you know better...but sadly that's often not the case.

Not exactly...people who go to Purgatory are on their way to Heaven. They are being purified of their sins since nothing unclean can enter Heaven. Some people go straight to Heaven, if they die in a state of grace. Some go straight to Hell, if that's what they choose. But nobody goes from Purgatory to Hell. I hope I'm not coming off as arrogant - I'm just trying to correct misconceptions.

Variability is one of the virtues of a woman. It avoids the crude requirement of polygamy. So long as you have one good wife you are sure to have a spiritual harem.
-G.K. Chesterton

A few things to note:
1. The Pope didn't say anything new, just reworded old teaching that everyone knew about before.
2. The media reported what he said incorrectly.
3. The Vatican released their statement to let the media know that they were wrong about what Pope Francis said, not that Pope Francis was wrong about what he said.
4. The media again reported the statement incorrectly by saying they were correcting the Pope.
To summarize: Christ died to redeem everyone, including atheists, Jainists, Muslims, and what have you. That part's not new, as much as the media have sensationalized it. Salvation, however, is dependent on accepting God, since He's not going to force Himself on you. The Pope is not a Universalist, who believes that everyone bar none is going to Heaven no matter what. The Pope is not a Pelagian, who believes that a person can earn Heaven on their own, without Christ. If the people reporting things actually knew any Catholic doctrine, the speech he made would have been a non-issue.

I don't think you're too skinny. I think you look extremely attractive the way you are. And I'm the sort of person who doesn't like overly-skinny women. It depends on their body types. Some people are meant to have a bit more weight on them and they look good with it, so they would look bad if they weighed as much as you. It's more about how healthy you look. You look like you're around the exact weight you should be in order to maximize your attractiveness, so don't worry about that. I think the vast majority of straight guys would think you're attractive and not see any "chicken legs" or "knobby knees" that you're worried about.
edit: I'm also not saying you wouldn't be attractive any more if you put on a few pounds. You'd still look good, I think. There are also people recommending that you put on muscle, which I would totally be behind, mostly because I find strong, tough women incredibly hot. I may be slightly biased because of that though...

Always found tough women incredibly attractive and sexy. Especially if they can fight well in addition to being athletic. Growing up I had a thing for Buffy, Xena, and some female wrestlers. You've got a lucky boyfriend.

You have pronounced nasolabial folds (google it). It's a facial feature that typically doesn't appear until the mid-20s. It's the fact that you have them that makes you look much older than 17. Possibly other things too, but that's what stood out most for me.
